items.title: Deprecation warning due to invalid escape sequences
items.body:
**Overview**

Deprecation warnings are raised due to invalid escape sequences. This can be fixed by using raw strings or escaping the literals. pyupgrade also helps in automatic conversion : https://github.com/asottile/pyupgrade/

**How to reproduce**

```
find . -iname '*.py' | grep -Ev 'test.py' | xargs -P4 -I{} python3.8 -Wall -m py_compile {}
./ibm_watson/visual_recognition_v3.py:197: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \ 
  """
./ibm_watson/visual_recognition_v3.py:359: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \ 
  """
```

**Additional information:**
- Which version of `Python` are you using? 3.8

    import ibm_watson
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/ibm_watson/__init__.py", line 16, in <module>
    from ibm_cloud_sdk_core import IAMTokenManager, DetailedResponse, BaseService, ApiException
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/ibm_cloud_sdk_core/__init__.py", line 16, in <module>

  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/ibm_cloud_sdk_core/base_service.py", line 26, in <module>

    from .jwt_token_manager import JWTTokenManager
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/ibm_cloud_sdk_core/jwt_token_manager.py", line 17, in <module>
    import jwt
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/jwt/__init__.py", line 19, in <module>

    from typing import Callable, Dict, List, Optional, Union # NOQA
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/typing.py", line 1357, in <module>

items.title: AssistantV1.update_workspace breaks with Autocomplete set in skill
items.body:
**Overview**
while updating a skill with Autocomplete setting you will get an exception
**Scenario:** get json from development skill and update a test environment skill with the data from development

**Cause** WorkspaceSystemSettings  is missing stuff for spelling_auto_correct.
I think an earlier version of the SDK just ignored this and did not update it's setting (we did it by hand back then) but now it gives an error

**Expected behavior**
Update the Autocomplete setting in the skill being updated

_You could argue that this is a new feature because it never updated this autocomplete, then the expected behavior would be that it should not stop the update (it should just ignore the unknown key)_

**Actual behavior**
exception that stops the update
ValueError: Unrecognized keys detected in dictionary for class WorkspaceSystemSettings: spelling_auto_correct

**How to reproduce**

1. Create a workspace/skill
2. turn on Autocorrection (skill->options) (without turning it on the 'key' will be absent in step 3)
3. use sdk AssistantV1.get_workspace() to get the workspace
3. update the skill with AssistantV1.update_workspace() with basically itself by using the data extracted from step 3's json.

**SDK Version**
tested with 3.2 and 3.3

## Schedule

We plan to release v4 in late September 2019 and a release candidate in early September 2019. This issue will be updated with more specifics on timings.

## Breaking Changes
- [x] As python 2.x will retire in December 2019, we will no longer support it
- [x] Decouple authentication mechanism from service constructor (still under discussion)

This issue will be used to track features and changes we want to make in the next major release of this package. We welcome community feedback on these goals - do people want these things? Are there other implementations/packages we should be looking at? Any comments are appreciated!

items.title: Issues with Python SDK in function "assistant.update_workspace"
items.body:
Describe the bug
When using the Python SDK and the function "assistant.update_workspace" (v1) calls, to upload a new JSON workspace, it crashes with an error due to incorrectly formatted "Search skill" rich response.


### Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. In Premium or Plus Assistant Instance, create a new dialog skill.
1. Add a few dialog nodes, making sure that one of the dialog nodes includes the "Search Skill" rich response type. - Include as the query parameter.
1. Save and exit dialog skill.
1. Export/download the resulting workspace skill JSON file to your pc.
1. Using a python application which includes the function assistant.update_workspace to push the just saved JSON file back to the dialog skill.

### Error given:
```
watson_developer_cloud.watson_service.WatsonApiException: 
Error: Invalid Request Body, 
Code: 400, 
Information: {
u'errors': [
 { u'path': u'.dialog_nodes[6105].output.generic[0]', u'message': u'must contain query when response_type is search_skill'},
 { u'path': u'.dialog_nodes[6105].output.generic[0]', u'message': u'must contain query_type when response_type is search_skill'}
]},
X-dp-watson-tran-id: 6294489336d063789092ed1a29af4005 ,
X-global-transaction-id: 6294489336d063789092ed1a29af4005
```

If you remove the search skill output response element i.e. output `{}`

items.title: Example microphone-speech-to-text.py hangs at end
items.body:
**Overview**
Running the microphone-speech-to-text.py example hangs after CTRL-C to exit on Raspberry Pi. This is because the statements in the Except block are in the wrong order. Solution is below. 

**Expected behavior**
The program should exit normally

**Actual behavior**
The program hangs when CTRL-C is pressed

**How to reproduce**
Run the program as is. This is on a Raspberry Pi with Python3. Also tested on MacOS 10.14.4, but it does not hang.

**SDK Version**
v3.0.3

**Additional information:**
Raspbian, Python3

**Additional context**
The solution is to shutdown the services in reverse order in which they were created. This was tested on Raspi. The correct order is below (current code commented out):

```python
except KeyboardInterrupt:
    # stop recording
    # audio_source.completed_recording()
    # stream.stop_stream()
    # stream.close()
    # audio.terminate()
    stream.stop_stream()
    stream.close()
    audio.terminate()
    audio_source.completed_recording()
```

items.title: Authorization does not support using IAM tokens and region urls
items.body:
Remember, an issue is not the place to ask questions. You can use [Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/ibm-watson) for that, or you may want to start a discussion on the [dW Answers](https://developer.ibm.com/answers/questions/ask/?topics=watson).

Before you open an issue, please check if a similar issue already exists or has been closed before.

 **Check service status**

 1.  For service issues or 5xx errors, first, go to https://console.bluemix.net/status?tags=platform,runtimes,services&view=n:i and check the status of the service.
1.  If the service status is OK, continue with a bug report.

 ---

**Overview**
_What is the issue? Be concise and clear._
Authorization service should support to generate tokens when using only IAM API keys and should also support using region-based service urls passed just like other watson-developer-cloud SDKs (ie. Node.JS). 
At the moment it is impossible to pass in those parameters in any way since the is no support for those extra parameters although these are supported for specific service instances.

**Expected behavior**
_What did you expect to happen?_
It should be possible to generate tokens while authenticating using only IAM API tokens like:
authorization = Authorization(iam_apikey=MY_APIKEY, url=MY_SERVICE_URL)

**Actual behavior**
_What actually happened?_
An error is thrown:
```
TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'iam_apikey'
```

**How to reproduce**
_Help us to reproduce what you experienced. Include your code snippets (without credentials)_
```
authorization = Authorization(iam_apikey=MY_APIKEY)
```

**Screenshots**
_If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem._

**SDK Version**
_Please provide the SDK version here._
All

**Additional information:**
- OS: MacOS but from the code seems to be affecting all platforms.
- Which version of `Python` are you using? 3.7.2


**Additional context**
_Add any other details about the problem._
The Authorization constructor should infer from the passed-in parameters the usage even when an empty or None object is passed such as :
```
authorization = Authorization(username=None, password=None, iam_apikey=MY_APIKEY)
```
to be consistent with the behavior of other Watson Developer Cloud SDKs.

items.title: SpeechToTextV1: Error when authenticating with ibm-credentials.env
items.body:
**Overview**
SpeechToTextV1 Service with ibm-credentials.env file

**Expected behavior**
SpeechToTextV1 (with apikey and url) should be initiated and recognize should work  

**Actual behavior**
`watson_developer_cloud.watson_service.WatsonApiException: Error: Provided API key could not be found, Code: 400`
When copying the api key and url directly to `SpeechToTextV1(url="", iam_apikey="")` it works fine without failures.

**How to reproduce**
Environment variable `IBM_CREDENTIALS_FILE` is set and accessed, otherwise it would be a different error. I have an apikey with upper and lowercase characters and numbers.

```
service = SpeechToTextV1()

with open(join(dirname(__file__), './.', 'C:\\Users\\...), 'rb') as audio_file:
    speech_recognition_results = service.recognize(
        audio=audio_file,
        content_type='audio/wav',
        word_alternatives_threshold=0.9,
        word_confidence=True,
        timestamps=True,
        profanity_filter=False,
        smart_formatting=True,
        speaker_labels=True
    ).get_result()
```

I could determine that the apikey is lowered before submitting in the request.

In watson_service.py I found:
```
def load_from_credential_file(self, service_name, separator='='):
        […]
        if credential_file_path is not None:
            with open(credential_file_path, 'r') as fp:
                for line in fp:
                    key_val = line.strip().split(separator)
                    if len(key_val) == 2:
                        self._set_credential_based_on_type(service_name, key_val[0].lower(), key_val[1].lower())
```

When changing the last line to

` self._set_credential_based_on_type(service_name, key_val[0].lower(), key_val[1])`

the program now runs without failure. 

**SDK Version**
2.8.0

**Additional information:**
- OS: Windows x64
- Python: 3.7

items.title: Update Workspace Bug - missing "disabled" field in node model for MCR
items.body:
SDK Version: Any
Python Version: Any
API: Watson Assistant
Method: update workspace

There is a bug in update_worpskace method. The SDK uses a node model which does not have `disabled` field making the workspace import incorrect in some special scenario. With Curl the issue does not happen.

Steps to Reproduce:
1) Create a new workspace and create a welcome node
2) Turn on `Multiple Responses` in welcome node
3) Turn off `Multiple Responses` in welcome node 
4) Export the JSON
5) Import using python SDK update_worpskace method.
6) In new workspace, the welcome node will have `Multiple Responses` turned on. If you test in chat, the output text will appear twice.

In the exported JSON, there is a `disabled:true` flag for the multiple response node. This disabled flag disappears when imported via SDK.

The root cause seems, the node model does not have the `disabled` field.

items.title: Ending recording with Speech-to-Text API
items.body:
As far as I can see, if you have both the `is_buffer` and `is_recording` flags set on an AudioSource, there is no way to stop streaming the audio. This means that, even if you stop the AudioSource's `input` from sending any more data, that thread is still going to be running indefinitely. It also stops you from closing the connection nicely.

[Here is the relevant code section.](https://github.com/watson-developer-cloud/python-sdk/blob/9d8ea23d1919c06175dd1865db9b1868d8466c6f/watson_developer_cloud/websocket/recognize_listener.py#L117-L132)

I might be missing something and there is a way to stop it, but if not I can add in a way. A simple `finished` flag in the AudioSource should do the trick.

#### python sdk version
2.5.0
#### python version
2.7

items.title: SDK AssistantV2 ignores user context variable
items.body:
#### Expected behavior
1) In AssistantV2, users should be able to set user-defined context variable in "message" API , same as AssistantV1  
2)  In AssistantV2 , option{'return_context': 'true'} should include latest context info in response.

#### Actual behavior
1) Python SDK - AssistantV1 handles user context correctly, but AssistantV2 ignores the user context.
(only "global.system" context like "user_id/time_zone/turn_count" remains)

It seems that the following code(_convert_model in watson_service.py) removes the user variable from the context in `assistant_v2.py`
```py 
    def message(self,
                assistant_id,
                session_id,
                input=None,
                context=None,
                **kwargs):
        ...
        if context is not None:
            context = self._convert_model(context, MessageContext)
```
2) in AssistantV2' ,option{'return_context': 'true'} doesn't return context.

#### Steps to reproduce the problem

1) In dialog, set "Hi, $(myname) ." on welcome box.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9675895/48747648-46745700-ecb7-11e8-8a96-4114b2066d4d.png)
2) set context "myname" and kick "message" API in AssistantV1 -> OK. = "Hi, ishida" returns.
3) same as above in AssistantV2 -> NG. = "Hi, " returns.( context is ignored )

#### Code snippet (Note: Do not paste your credentials)
##### AssistantV1(OK)
```py
from watson_developer_cloud import AssistantV1
iam_apikey='XXXXXXXXXX'
workspace_id = 'XXXXXXXX'
assistant = AssistantV1(
    iam_apikey=iam_apikey,
    version='2018-07-10')
response = assistant.message(
    workspace_id=workspace_id,
    context={
        'myname': 'ishida'
    }).get_result()
print(response)
```
```
--> {'intents': [], 'entities': [], 'input': {}, 'output': {'generic': [{'response_type': 'text', 'text': 'Hi, ishida .'}], 'text': ['Hi, ishida .'], 'nodes_visited': ['Opening'], 'log_messages': []}, 'context': {'myname': 'ishida', 'conversation_id': '1d45053c-d7e6-4037-99be-57868397e7a7', 'system': {'initialized': True, 'dialog_stack': [{'dialog_node': 'root'}], 'dialog_turn_counter': 1, 'dialog_request_counter': 1, '_node_output_map': {'Opening': [0]}, 'branch_exited': True, 'branch_exited_reason': 'completed'}, 'no_reservation': True}}
```
##### AssistantV2(NG)
```py
from watson_developer_cloud import AssistantV2
assistant_id = 'XXXXXXXXXX'
iam_apikey='XXXXXXXXXX',
assistant = AssistantV2(
    iam_apikey=iam_apikey,
    version='2018-11-08')
session_id = assistant.create_session(assistant_id).get_result()
message = assistant.message(
    assistant_id,
    session_id["session_id"],
    options={

print(message)

```
```
--> {'output': {'generic': [{'response_type': 'text', 'text': 'Hi,  .'}], 'intents': [], 'entities': []}}
```

watson-developer-cloud   2.4.1

Python 3.6.4

items.title: Adding compression to microphone-speech-to-text.py
items.body:
I wonder if anyone has succeeded in adding Opus or FLAC compression to the microphone-speech-to-text.py model. The pyaudio package only returns uncompressed chunks, which means the amount of data passed to the STT endpoint is rather large. The microphone-speech-to-text.py program works well, but I'm hoping to reduce or eliminate reaching the 100 Mb recognition request limit, which at a bitrate of 16000 comes every 55 minutes or so. Any guidance on how to do this would be very much appreciated.

Thank you.

items.title: Add support for Text To Speech Web Sockets

```py
class TTSWSClientProtocol(WebSocketClientProtocol):

  def __init__(self):
    WebSocketClientProtocol.__init__(self)
    self.msgs = []
    self.binaryBytesReceived = 0

  def onConnect(self, response):
    logging.info('onConnect')

  def onOpen(self):
    logging.info('onOpen')
    self.sendMessage(json.dumps({'text': 'Hello <mark name="here"/> world',
                                 'accept': 'audio/ogg;codecs=opus'}))

  def onMessage(self, msg, binary):
    if binary:
      logging.info('binary message: %s bytes received', len(msg))
      self.binaryBytesReceived += len(msg)
    else:
      logging.info(msg)
      self.msgs.append(json.loads(msg))

  def onClose(self, wasClean, code, reason):
    logging.info((wasClean, code, reason))
```

websocket-client 0.53.0 breaks speech_to_text.recognize_using_websocket

Repro:  on Python 3.6 64 Bit on Windows 10

Run sample recognize_using_websocket code, call back is never received. Step into debugger and observe how line 229 in  \python36_64\lib\site-packages\websocket\_app.py hangs:

```
            self.sock.connect(
                self.url, header=self.header, cookie=self.cookie,
                http_proxy_host=http_proxy_host,
                http_proxy_port=http_proxy_port, http_no_proxy=http_no_proxy,
                http_proxy_auth=http_proxy_auth, subprotocols=self.subprotocols,
                host=host, origin=origin)
```

Solution: downgrade to old version of web sockets: pip install websocket-client==0.47.0

items.title: i want to record  this code for 5 second only i dont want to press ctrl+c and response time also good
items.body:
#### Expected behavior

5 seconds recording only
#### Actual behavior

we need to press ctrl + c 

#### Code snippet (Note: Do not paste your credentials)
```py
# You need to install pyaudio to run this example
# pip install pyaudio

# When using a microphone, the AudioSource `input` parameter would be
# initialized as a queue. The pyaudio stream would be continuously adding
# recordings to the queue, and the WebSocket client would be sending the
# recordings to the speech to text service

from __future__ import print_function
import pyaudio
from watson_developer_cloud import SpeechToTextV1
from watson_developer_cloud.websocket import RecognizeCallback, AudioSource
from threading import Thread

try:
    from Queue import Queue, Full
except ImportError:
    from queue import Queue, Full

###############################################
#### Initalize queue to store the recordings ##
###############################################
CHUNK = 1024
# Note: It will discard if the websocket client can't consumme fast enough
# So, increase the max size as per your choice
BUF_MAX_SIZE = CHUNK * 10
# Buffer to store audio
q = Queue(maxsize=int(round(BUF_MAX_SIZE / CHUNK)))

# Create an instance of AudioSource
audio_source = AudioSource(q, True, True)

###############################################
#### Prepare Speech to Text Service ########
###############################################

# initialize speech to text service
speech_to_text = SpeechToTextV1(
    username='YOUR SERVICE USERNAME',
    password='YOUR SERVICE PASSWORD',
    url='https://stream.watsonplatform.net/speech-to-text/api')

# define callback for the speech to text service
class MyRecognizeCallback(RecognizeCallback):
    def __init__(self):
        RecognizeCallback.__init__(self)

    def on_transcription(self, transcript):
        print(transcript)

    def on_connected(self):
        print('Connection was successful')

    def on_error(self, error):
        print('Error received: {}'.format(error))

    def on_inactivity_timeout(self, error):
        print('Inactivity timeout: {}'.format(error))

    def on_listening(self):
        print('Service is listening')

    def on_hypothesis(self, hypothesis):
        print(hypothesis)

    def on_data(self, data):
        print(data)

    def on_close(self):
        print("Connection closed")

# this function will initiate the recognize service and pass in the AudioSource
def recognize_using_weboscket(*args):
    mycallback = MyRecognizeCallback()
    speech_to_text.recognize_using_websocket(audio=audio_source,
                                             content_type='audio/l16; rate=44100',
                                             recognize_callback=mycallback)

###############################################
#### Prepare the for recording using Pyaudio ##
###############################################

# Variables for recording the speech
FORMAT = pyaudio.paInt16
CHANNELS = 1
RATE = 44100

# define callback for pyaudio to store the recording in queue
def pyaudio_callback(in_data, frame_count, time_info, status):
    try:
        q.put(in_data)
    except Full:
        pass # discard
    return (None, pyaudio.paContinue)

# instantiate pyaudio
audio = pyaudio.PyAudio()

# open stream using callback
stream = audio.open(
    format=FORMAT,
    channels=CHANNELS,
    rate=RATE,
    input=True,
    frames_per_buffer=CHUNK,
    stream_callback=pyaudio_callback,
    start=False
)

#########################################################################
#### Start the recording and start service to recognize the stream ######
#########################################################################

print("Enter CTRL+C to end recording...")
stream.start_stream()

try:
    recognize_thread = Thread(target=recognize_using_weboscket, args=())
    recognize_thread.start()

    while True:
        pass
except KeyboardInterrupt:
    # stop recording
    audio_source.completed_recording()
    stream.stop_stream()
    stream.close()
audio.terminate()
```

# Response time is good but I want for 5 second and recording second should be configured

#### python version
3.0

    input=True,
    frames_per_buffer=CHUNK)

print('recording....')
with open(tmp.name, 'w') as f:
    for i in range(0, int(RATE / CHUNK * RECORD_SECONDS)):

        f.write(data)

stream.stop_stream()
stream.close()
audio.terminate()
print('Done recording...')
print ("Request Sent Time:" + str(time.time()))
t1 = datetime.datetime.now()
with open(tmp.name) as f:
    speech_to_text.recognize_with_websocket(audio=f,recognize_callback=mycallback)
```

```
from watson_developer_cloud import SpeechToTextV1, ToneAnalyzerV3
from watson_developer_cloud.websocket import RecognizeCallback
import json

class MyRecognizeCallback(RecognizeCallback):
    def __init__(self):
        RecognizeCallback.__init__(self)

    def on_data(self, data):
        print(json.dumps(data, indent=2))

    def on_error(self, error):
        print('Error received: {}'.format(error))

    def on_inactivity_timeout(self, error):
        print('Inactivity timeout: {}'.format(error))

speech_to_text = SpeechToTextV1(...)

myRecognizeCallback = MyRecognizeCallback()

with open(..., 'rb') as audio_file:
    speech_to_text.recognize_using_websocket(
        audio=audio_file,
        content_type='audio/flac',
        model='en-US_BroadbandModel',
        recognize_callback=myRecognizeCallback,
        interim_results=True,
        speaker_labels=True)

```
#### python sdk version
watson-developer-cloud   1.6.0

#### python version
Python 3.5.5 :: Anaconda, Inc.

### proposed solution
In speech_to_text_websocket_listener.py

line 129 to 132:
```
            elif 'results' in json_object or 'speaker_labels' in json_object:
                hypothesis = ''
                # empty hypothesis
                if json_object['results']:
```

changed to :
```
            elif 'results' in json_object or 'speaker_labels' in json_object:
                hypothesis = ''
                # empty hypothesis
                if 'results' in json_object:
```

And line 142 &143, call 'on_data' even if result not in json_object.
```
                    self.callback.on_transcription(transcripts)
                    self.callback.on_data(json_object)
```
To
```
                    self.callback.on_transcription(transcripts)
                self.callback.on_data(json_object)
```

items.title: Main thread blocks
items.body:
It appears that when speech_to_text.recognize_with_websocket call is made, the execution happens on the main thread (the thread which made call to  speech_to_text.recognize_with_websocket)

Therefore main thread blocks, even though results comes in async fashion (by invoking appropriate methods from the class passed as  recognize_callback parameter to the call above.

Since it's async call back model is used, should SDK handle threading and ensure that main execution is not blocked (by calling creating a second thread and calling peech_to_text.recognize_with_websocket on that thread)?

Snippets:

```

with open ("blah.mp3"], 'rb') as audio_file:	
		speech_to_text.recognize_with_websocket(
		audio=audio_file,
		content_type='audio/mp3',
		model='en-US_NarrowbandModel',
		recognize_callback=myRecognizeCallback,
		interim_results=False,
		keywords=["blah"],
		keywords_threshold=0.5,
		speaker_labels=True,
		timestamps=True,
		max_alternatives=3)


              #### PROBLEM. EXECUTION DOES NOT GO TO NEXT LINE UNTIL RESULTS COME BACK
              while not myRecognizeCallback.event.is_set():
	 	     print ("Waiting")

class MyRecognizeCallback(RecognizeCallback):
        ...
	def on_data(self, data):
		...
		with open ("dump.txt", "w") as file:
			file.write (json.dumps(data, indent=2))
		self.event.set()
```


Python: 3.6

thanks

)

environment_info = discovery.list_environment('{environment_id}')
print(json.dumps(environment_info, indent=2))
```

`list_environment` should be `get_environment`.

items.title: Rename `iam_api_key` to be `iam_apikey` like in our other sdks
Raspberry - STT, Assistant, TTS response time
items.body:
Hi, 

I made an assistant that uses Watson's STT, Assistant and TTS. 

In my code I used pyaudio (like in the example provided in microphone-speech-to-text.py) to record 2-3 seconds of audio, then I pass that audio to Watson STT using speech_to_text.recognize which returns a text that I pass to Watson Assistant. Then I pass the result to Waton TTS (always using the code provided in the example) which then give me a .wav that I play using vlc.MediaPlayer. 

I did some testing on raspberry and the problem is that the whole response time is too long. I have different intents on my assistant and I tested them all putting on an excel file the response time of each service. These are the average responses time: STT 3,48 seconds, Assistant 0,62 seconds, TTS 2 seconds. On average the response in audio is played after 6 seconds which is a very long time. 
My question is: Is it somehow possible to reduce the response time? STT is the service that takes too much to return a result and in some cases it takes 5 seconds. Here is the excel file of response time
[tempi.xlsx](https://github.com/watson-developer-cloud/python-sdk/files/2202202/tempi.xlsx)



STT
```
transcript = ''
	#mettere il model
    try:
        with open(recording_name,'rb') as f:
            dictResponse = speech_to_text.recognize(audio=f, content_type='audio/l16; rate=44100')
            #print(json.dumps(dictResponse,indent=2))
            if dictResponse["results"]:
                transcript = dictResponse["results"][0]["alternatives"][0]["transcript"]
                print('transcript: {}'.format(transcript))
            else:
                print("no results from stt")
                transcript = ""
    except Exception as e:
        print('speech2text error: {}'.format(e))

    doneSTT = time.time()
    print("--> STT time: {}".format(doneSTT-doneRecording))
```

Assistant
```
#input to watson assistant
    response=''
    try:
        response = assistant.message(
        workspace_id=workspace_id,
        input={
            'text': transcript
        },
        context={
            'metadata': {
                'deployment': 'myDeployment'
            }
        })
    except Exception as e:
        print("Assistant error: {}".format(e))
    
    
        
    
    #watson response
    #print(json.dumps(response,indent=2))
    if response["intents"]:
        intents = response["intents"][0]
        intent = intents["intent"]
        intentConfidence = response["intents"][0]["confidence"]
        print('intent name: {}, confidence: {}'.format(intent, intentConfidence))
    else:
        print("intent not found")


        if response["output"]:
            risposta = response["output"]["text"][0]
            print('risposta: {}'.format(risposta))
        else:
            print("no output from assistant")
```

TTS and response playback
```
try:
            with open(outputName,'wb') as audio_file:
                audio_file.write(text_to_speech.synthesize(risposta, accept='audio/wav',voice="en-US_AllisonVoice").content)
            #audio_file.write(text_to_speech.synthesize(risposta, accept='audio/wav',voice="it-IT_FrancescaVoice").content)
        except Exception as e:
            print("Text2speech error: {}".format(e))
            
            
        doneTTS = time.time()
        print("--> TTS time: {}".format(doneTTS-doneAssistant))

        #play response
        player = vlc.MediaPlayer("/home/pi/Downloads/stt-assistant-rasp-backup/response.wav")
        player.play()
        
        endResponse = time.time()
        
        print("--> time elapsed: {}".format(endResponse-doneRecording))
```

Any help would be appreciated, thanks.

#### python sdk version
1.5
#### python version
default python3 on raspberry

items.title: wrong content type for metadata in add_document
items.body:
#### Expected behavior
mime type for metadata should be `application/json`

#### Actual behavior
it's `text/plain` so WDS API doesn't accept it

#### Steps to reproduce the problem
just upload document with metadata

#### Code snippet (Note: Do not paste your credentials)
```
        metadata_tuple = (None, metadata, 'text/plain')
```

#### python sdk version
1.4.1

#### python version
2.7

items.title: Pass Entity into Message Request
items.body:
Hello, i am using Pyhton 3.5.2 and the latest version 1.4.0 of this python-sdk.

For a use case, the user should choose a contact name from a contact list (which is stored as an entity in IBM Watson Assistant). 
So, possibly, there are multiple contact names matching the user input e.g. when only the firstname is given by the user. For example "michael" gives back 4 suitable contact names. Therefore, i present the 4 names (with fullname)  and the user should choose one of them.

Therefore i want to use the possibility to pass the already filtered contact entity values (4 contacts) into the second bot request, as stated in the documentation https://www.ibm.com/watson/developercloud/assistant/api/v1/python.html?python#message. Beside the `context`, it is also possible to pass the `entities`:

> Entities to use when evaluating the message. Include entities from the previous response to continue using those entities rather than detecting entities in the new input.

I did that with this python example:

```python
# IBM API Text Request
response = ibm_conversation.message(
   workspace_id=ibm_workspace,
   input={'text': message.lower()},
   context=response["context"],  # context from the previous request
   entities=response["context"]["entities"]  #recognized entities from the previous request
)
```

However, the result of the second request is not as expected. There are still 4 entity values detected (the same that i passed into the message request) and all of them were matched to the second user input text which is not correct.

Example:
First user input:
> "i want to call michael"

First answer:
> Okay, there are 4 contact matching: "Michael W, Michael Z, Michael Y, Michael Z. Please choose one!".

Second user input:
> "Okay, i choose Z".

Second bot answer:
> Okay, there are 4 contact matching: "Michael W, Michael Z, Michael Y, Michael Z. Please choose one!"

It is because in the response, i see that the string "Z" is extracted as the four entities.

For me it would be logical to only get the "Michael Z" as extracted entity for the user input message "Okay, i choose Z".

The main goal of this, is that there are also other contact names with the lastname "Z", so when i do not pass the already filtered entity from the first bot response into the second bot request, it gives me back all contacts matching "Z" and this is not what i want.

Any suggestions?
Thanks!
Josef
